p: As regards excretions and secretions, it has been demonstrated that they might contain viable virus (1.6â€“4.8 log 10HAD 50/mL) ( Table 1) on the day of euthanasia, but in the case of contact animals, the virus was molecularly detected in nasal fluid prior to being evident in blood ( 38). ASFV survivability in these contaminated excretions depends mainly on temperature; however, in favourable conditions it may retain its viability for long time, increasing the risk of the disease spreading, particularly under low-biosecurity conditions ( 13).
